Universal Prevention Activities
The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to the RMP-covered process at Sonora.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.
 
Specialized Safety Features:
 
The Sonora Gas Plant has safety features on many units to help:
I.	contain/control a release
II.	quickly detect a release
III.	reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release

Release Detection
I.	LEL monitors
a.	Installed between each #1 through #10 recompression compressor with automatic shutdown of the compressors on either side of the monitor
b.	Installed on each #11 through #14 recompression compressor with automatic shutdown of the compressor
c.	Installed on each refrigeration compressor with automatic shutdown of the entire refrigeration compressor building
d.	Installed in the ceilings of each compressor building with automatic shutdown of all compressors within each respective building.
II.	Fire eyes 
a.	Installed on each recompression compressor with automatic shutdown of the  compressor
b.	Installed on each refrigeration compressor with automatic shutdown of the entire refrigeration compressor building
III.	Hydrocarbon monitors 
a.	Fuel monitors installed on each #11 through #14 recompression compressor with automatic shutdown of the compressor
b.	Propane monitors installed on each refrigeration compressor with automatic shutdown of the entire refrigeration compressor building
IV.	Routine operator rounds/equipment inspections
V.	Operators are on-site continually (8,760 hours per year)

Accidental Release Prevention Policy:
Protecting and responsibly managing natural resources demonstrates stewardship and is critical to the quality of life in the communities we serve, to the environment, and to WTG South Permian Midstream LLC's (WTG's) long-term business success.  Promoting the health and safety of co-workers, contractors, customers, and communities is the responsibility of all WTG employees.  WTG will comply with all applicable laws, rules, and regulations.
 
Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:
Sonora Gas Plant (Sonora), located near Midkiff, Upton County, Texas, is a natural gas liquids processing plant that produces pipeline specification residue gas and natural gas liquids from field gas collected throughout the gathering system.  Sonora handles flammable gas and liquid mixtures in an amount greater than the threshold quantity containing one of more of the following RMP-regulated constituents:
¿	Methane
¿	Ethane
¿	Propane
¿	Isobutane
¿	Butane
¿	Isopentane
¿	Pentane
 
The only RMP-regulated toxic constituent present at Sonora, which is part of the amine treating process, is hydrogen sulfide; however, quantities at Sonora are well below the threshold quantity. 
 
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:
WTG is committed to ensuring a safe work environment for all its employees, contractors, and vendors.  The Sonora Gas Plant has a detailed Emergency Action Plan in which it has coordinated with the community's local responders in an effort to introduce them to the facility and its personnel.
 
General Accidental Release Prevention Program:
The Sonora process is covered by OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of highly hazardous chemicals (PSM) regulation.  WTG considers the systems developed for compliance with PSM to be the basis for good safety and business practices.  In this effort, WTG identifies opportunities to continuously improve initiatives for each PSM element.  The PSM

elements are implemented to satisfy the PSM/RMP requirements since the Sonora Gas Plant now qualifies as a program level 3 RMP process when previously it qualified as a program level 1 RMP process.  
 
Employee Participation:
Employee participation is the foundation block to an evergreen and integrated PSM program.  Thus, the current PSM improvement initiative is heavily focused on this key element as employees are becoming more actively involved in the implementation of each element of PSM.
 
Process Safety Information:
Comprehensive reviews of the available process safety information (PSI) have been conducted.  Updates to the maximum intended inventory (MII) and development of new piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs) have been completed.  Area classification drawings are under development along with material balances for completion estimated in late 2019.  A comprehensive electronic web-based system utilized for timely access to information has been built, implemented, and made available to all personnel involved with process operations.  
 
Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):
A new PHA procedure has been established for WTG.  A new comprehensive PHA team including a highly experienced third-party PHA facilitator, experienced WTG operating personnel (operations and maintenance), WTG engineers, Process Control personnel, safety representatives, and PSM representatives were utilized to conduct a PHA redo from October 8 through November 1, 2018.  Results and recommendations from these analyses have been shared with employees.  Additionally, a process safety tracking tool has been developed and implemented for the interactive tracking of PHA action items to closure.
 
Operating Procedures:
A gap analysis and completion of all discovered gaps in Sonora operating procedures is in process.  Operating procedures will be updated to reflect current operations and identified gaps in operating procedures (such as various modes of process operations) will be dev

eloped.  After the operating procedures are completed, they will be published to the company's electronic web-based system and used in the operations training program.  
 
Management of Change (MOC) and Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR):
Improvements to the MOC procedure and associated checklists are in progress to capture all process related changes.  Requirements for the identification, evaluation, control, and authorization of modifications to plant design and operations prior to the implementation to ensure that the risk of new or existing hazards are properly managed is available to all personnel.  Extensive PSSR checklists for applicable disciplines (electrical, instrumentation, procedures, etc.) have been developed and implemented.  These checklists are Appendices to the Company's MOC procedure and are available online from the company's electronic web-based process library. 
 
Mechanical Integrity (MI):
A third-party contractor has developed global WTG MI procedures.  In addition to the ultrasonic thickness testing program already in practice at Sonora, a complete third-party MI gap assessment was recently completed.  The identified MI gaps have been addressed and are being used to develop comprehensive inspection standards and procedures along with a specialized inspection program structured specifically for Sonora.  The Sonora MI program has been designed and implemented as of July 2019.
 
Incident Investigation:
WTG investigates all PSM incidents.  Throughout the PSM program assessment process, incident investigation procedures are being reviewed and will be updated as necessary.  A mix of WTG personnel will be provided investigation methodology training to further enhance the program and ensure root cause is consistently identified.  A process safety tracking tool has been developed and implemented to track action items and incident investigation corrective actions to closure.  Third-party contractors will coordinate the investigation of any high

-risk incidents. 
 
Compliance Audits:
To meet compliance with PSM, WTG conducts compliance audits every three years to verify all PSM element requirements are being satisfied.  In WTG's general PSM improvement program initiatives, an updated audit protocol has been established and implemented within WTG.  A new team including experienced PSM representatives, WTG engineering, operating personnel (operations and maintenance), and safety representatives will be utilized to conduct a new PSM Compliance Audit later this year.  The last audit conducted at Sonora was on December 31, 2018.  Results and action items from the new audit will be shared with employees.  Additionally, a process safety tracking tool has been developed and implemented for the interactive tracking of PSM compliance action items to closure.
  
Hot Work Permit:
Hot work permits are in use and on file.  These permits are uploaded onto the company's electronic web-based process library.  Throughout the PSM program assessment process, all hot work procedures are being reviewed and will be updated as necessary.
 
Contractors:
WTG has an electronic program for contractors that includes their safety records.  A review of the contractor's safety record both prior to selection and during their time of employment has been developed.  Written contractor and visitor safety orientation training materials have been developed and implemented at Sonora.  WTG is in process of developing a safety training video that all contractors and visitors must see before gaining access to the Sonora Gas Plant.
 
Training:
With the enhancement of various PSM elements such as PSI, PHAs, operating procedures, PSSR, MI, MOC, incident investigations, etc., additional training (computer and classroom based) will be established to ensure all Sonora employees are knowledgeable in these processes.

Release mitigation measures include:
I.	Fire extinguishing systems located throughout all compressor buildings
II.	Personnel trained in the site's emergency response plan
III.	Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)
 
Emergency Response Program:
The overall emergency response program for Sonora has been coordinated with several local emergency responders that include the Reagan County Sheriff's Department, Upton County Sheriff's Department, Big Lake Fire Department/EMS, Rankin Volunteer Fire Department/EMS, Big Lake Highway Patrol, Midland Highway Patrol, and local medical providers.  The Sonora Gas Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department, Police and Sheriff's office).  This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  Sonora may implement mock emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations and will conduct additional emergency drills annually with local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the facility.
 
Five-Year Accident History:
A primary loss of containment incident occurred on April 23, 2020 when a gasket failure between the second stage suction and discharge bottles on the #6 residue recompressor resulted in the release of residue (sales) gas.  The released gas contacted an ignition source that resulted in a fire.  Sonora operators began an Emergency Shutdown (ESD) immediately upon detection of the fire to isolate the equipment from the process and the fire was quickly extinguished.  A total of 71,755 pounds of a flamm

able gas mixture was released over a period of 10 minutes.  The fire resulted in significant onsite property damage at the #6 recompressor with no operator or contractor injuries.  There were no known offsite impacts.  This incident is being reported under the RMP accident history reporting requirements per 40 CFR 68.195(a).  There have been no other accidental releases of regulated substances meeting the accident reporting criteria of 40 CFR 68.42(a) during the prior five years.
 
Planned Changes to Improve Safety
WTG Sonora will continue to improve its safety and environmental performance through emphasis on the continued development of its PSM Program.  Improvement plans include continued process engineering support to update critical PSI data for the site; updating operating procedures written for each mode of operation and to include consequences of deviations; an operator certification training program established from the new operating procedures, new process hazard analysis (PHA) procedure and team structure ensuring employee involvement, new MI program incorporating the implementation of all new inspection procedures and frequencies all to be carefully reviewed, and recommendations for improvement generated using WTG's new compliance audit process.
